snippet: The move came because Washington has refused to cooperate with German inquiries into United States intelligence officials, Berlin says.
abstract: German government demands removal of Central Intelligence Agency's Berlin chief, top American spy in country; action underscores fact that mounting revelations about widespread American intelligence operations there have gravely damaged relations between once close allies; move is likely to force another reassessment inside CIA and other spy agencies about whether espionage operations in friendly nations are worth risk to broader goals.

byline.original: By ALISON SMALE, MARK MAZZETTI and DAVID E. SANGER
byline.contributor: Alison Smale reported from Berlin, Mark Mazzetti from Washington and David E. Sanger from Vienna.

lead_paragraph: The move came because Washington has refused to cooperate with German inquiries into United States intelligence officials, Berlin says.

headline.main: Germany Demands Top U.S. Intelligence Officer Be Expelled
headline.print_headline: Germany to Oust Top C.I.A. Officer as a Rift Deepens
